content.text: Welcome! To begin reviewing the CLUE software, please click the My Resources bar at extreme left, and then click the tab labeled Lesson.

intro.title: Introduction
intro.placeholder: Add notes on this lesson's topic and goals.

labWork.title: Lab Work
labWork.placeholder: Discuss how to approach your experiment, take data, write programs.

problems.title: Lesson 1.1 How do Bionic Arms Work?

text: Objective:
During this lesson, we will explore emerging robotics technology that helps people with neurological conditions or missing limbs.
Let's Explore Energy Sticks!
Please watch the video to explore what energy sticks are: Energy Stick Video

Try creating some tiles in your workspace and write down some thoughts about what Energy sticks are and how they work. You can make text tiles (letter A), drawings (pencil), Tables and graphs, including pictures or photos, and even make programs, which we will work with in future lessons.
In their CLUE Workspace, students should reflect critically about their readings and any questions they have brainstormed. Have students try out some of the tools to document what they learned.
Experiment with Energy Sticks
Please pair up with the friend and play with the energy stick provided. While playing with it, you can try any of these activities:

• compare each partner holding one end of the energy stick with one hand and keeping your other hand at your sides with holding one end of the energy stick while simultaneously holding hands with your partner.
  • compare holding one end of the energy stick while simultaneously holding one end of a piece of wood (e.g., wooden spoon) with holding one end of the energy stick while simultaneously holding one end of a piece of metal (e.g., metal spoon).
Document the results of each experiment. Then try making up a few experiments of your own. What does each trial prove?
Programs to Express Closing a Circuit
We can use a program to turn lights on and off in the same way you just did with the Energy Sticks.
Here is a very simple program. Recreate this program with the program tool in your workspace. Then add some logic to make the lightbulb only turn on when the signal amplitude is over 0.5.
Programs are one way to express models of actual circuits.
DISCUSS
Let's Discuss your shared experience of playing with the energy sticks and what you have observed! Some questions you could think about are:

• What makes our classroom light glow? (Flick light switch off) Why does flicking the switch stop the light from glowing?
  • What conditions appear to be necessary to make the light stick glow? What conditions appear to be necessary to make the light stick not glow? How can this be explained?
How do Bionic Arms Work?
Please watch one of the following videos to learn about the bionic arms:
Tilly’s Bionic Arms
Beyond Robotics
Working in Groups

Please practice working in groups using the group sharing tools in CLUE. Switch to the Group View and share your documents. Swap ideas about what you saw in the Bionic Arm videos, and how you think they relate to the energy stick.
Drag the table below into your learning log, and fill it in for this experiment.
KWL JOURNAL

You will keep a journal of what you have learned throughout these lessons. Begin or Open a KWL Journal either from the File menu or from the My Work tab. Record today's date. Then drag the table below into your journal and fill it out.

content.name: After each activity, please record what you know, wonder, and learn about the topic.

problems.title: Lesson 1.2A What body systems contribute to limb movement
problems.subtitle: Part 1

text: Objective
During this lesson, we will measure their own reaction times, construct a model to communicate their current understanding, and investigate how neurological conditions could impact limb movement.
Let's measure our reaction times!
DISCUSS
Let's discuss how fast human limbs can react in day-to-day life (e.g., the time it takes to start crossing the street once the light changes to green). Some questions you could think about are:

• What affects limb reaction time (RT)?
  • Why is time to react important?
Document your thoughts in your workspace
WATCH
Please watch this video to explore what reaction time is all about.
Document in your worksheet what you learned in the video.
TRY
Please pair up with a friend and measure your reaction times using your dominant and non-dominant hands.
Please follow the instructions video here.
You can drag the data tables into your workspace to record your scores (You can also print out the form).
Use the lookup table to convert drop distance (in cm) to time (in thousands of a second).
Results Table
Drag these tables into your Workspace and fill them in to record and calculate your results
* indicates final results
If your teacher has provided a Google sheet, please enter your data there to compute the class average.
You may wish to create a Google sheet for your class to calculate the average scores for all students. Create a text region in a CLUE worksheet and put a link to the sheet.
TRY (Optional)
Please take a video of yourself catching an object and play it in slow motion. Please watch the
On iPhone: Go into the camera and click “Slo-mo” to take slow motion video
On Android: Go into the camera, click “video” and then select “slow motion” option.
Document the links to your videos in your workspace and share them with your class.
DISCUSS

Once one member from each group shares their model, please compare and contrast the models to identify what is similar and different and document these in your worksheet. You can use text, drawings, or any other representation that helps you talk about your model.
Similarities
Differences

After the Investigating how injury to different parts of the nervous system might impact limb movement group work (I am not sure how to structure these because the lesson will be jumping from group work to class work and class work to group work):
SHARE

Each group will share their findings for the question of how injury to different parts of the nervous system might impact limb movement. For this section, you can share your screen in group view (rectangle icon in the upper right of the screen). Or you can publish to Class Work (rectangle with up arrow in the upper left of the screen) and ask others to look at your model on their computers while one member of the group shares the group's results.
KWL JOURNAL

You will keep a journal of what you have learned throughout these lessons. Begin or Open a KWL Journal either from the File menu or from the My Work tab. Record today's date. Then drag the table below into your journal and fill it out.

problems.title: Lesson 1.2B What body systems contribute to limb movement
problems.subtitle: Part B

text: Marking the Components of the Nervous System
Please review this digital resource on the nervous system, and mark the components of the nervous system (brain, spinal cord, and peripheral nerves) on your model from the previous lesson.
Please list all body systems that affect our reaction time. Then, co-construct an illustrated and annotated model of the sequence of events associated with the reaction time activity.
List the body systems in a text tile in your workspace. Draw your model on the drawing tile.
DISCUSS
Select a member as a spokesperson to share your model with the class.
Investigating how injury to different parts of the nervous system might impact limb movement

Please select one of the following injuries to explore more, and then mark the location of the injury/disorder on your model and add text that communicates some ways you predict limb movement would be affected. (Here again, the students need to be able to mark on their model. So, a larger section for their model might be better.)
Brain Injury reference document
Spinal Cord Injury reference document
Peripheral Nerve Injury reference document
KWL JOURNAL

You will keep a journal of what you have learned throughout these lessons. Begin or Open a KWL Journal either from the File menu or from the My Work tab. Record today's date. Then drag the table below into your journal and fill it out.

content.name: After each activity, please record what you know, wonder, and learn about the topic.

text: Objective

During this section, we will explore how EMG signals can be used to control a robotic claw. For that, you will use electromyography (EMG) in coordination with a robotic claw to model the performance of a bionic arm.
Group Brainstorming Activity

Whenever you explore a scientific topic, it's a good idea to start by identifying what questions you want to answer. With your group, generate a list of questions about the biology of paralysis and the kinds of technology you think would be beneficial. You can work as a group by sharing your documents using the share button and turning on the group view. When you are ready, publish your questions to the class.

Make a new text box by clicking the 'A' tool in your workspace on the right. You can drag text blocks and images from the lesson into your page, and also from your group-mates' workspaces. You can drag images on your computer onto your workspace too.

In their CLUE Workspace journals, students should reflect critically about their readings and the questions they have brainstormed. Have students share what they observed during each type of stimulation. Then, ask students what the spike readings mean. Have students develop a quick sketch or description of how our brain communicates with our body. This will transition the class into the next section on neuron anatomy and action potentials.
Work with your group to find the signal strength and duration of axon signals. You might wish to organize your data in a table like the one below.
Mimicing Axons
We can turn a signal on and off just like an axon does using a program. We will make programs using blocks that are connected from their outputs to their inputs.
Here is a very simple program. Recreate this program with the program tool in your workspace. Then add some logic to make the lightbulb only turn on when the signal amplitude is over 0.5.
Discuss with your group to find the signal strength and duration of axon signals. You might wish to organize your data in a table like the one below.
Drag the table below into your learning log, and fill it in for this experiment.

content.name: Record what you know, wonder, and learn about the topic.
